importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the assassination attempt in May 2024 to the trial and verdict in October 2025 reflects the escalation of political tensions, public response, and legal proceedings in Slovakia.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court sentenced 72-year-old poet Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for a 'terror attack' after he shot Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula claimed the act was motivated by 'moral despair' and a desire to protest government policies, including halting military aid to Ukraine.
The prosecution reclassified the shooting as a 'terror attack' due to political motivation, shifting from premeditated murder charges.
Fico, now in his fourth term, has intensified his criticism of liberal opposition and media, and pushed Slovakia toward a more Russia-aligned, authoritarian foreign policy.
The incident has deepened political polarization, triggered mass protests, and raised concerns over democratic backsliding and human rights in Slovakia.
Cintula described Fico as 'drunk with power' and said his actions embodied years of national frustration, framing the shooting as a protest against political corruption and abuse of power.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced poet Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024, classifying the act as a 'terror attack' due to its political motivation. Cintula, from Levice, claimed he acted out of 'moral despair' and sought to protest government policies, particularly the halt of military aid to Ukraine. The incident has intensified political polarization, prompting widespread protests and criticism of Fico’s increasingly authoritarian governance, including crackdowns on media and NGOs, and a shift toward Russia-aligned foreign policy. Fico, who has repeatedly accused opposition and media of inciting the attack, has also pushed for reduced support of Ukraine and proposed a constitutional amendment restricting same-sex rights and asserting national law over EU law, raising concerns about democratic backsliding in Slovakia.
title: Slovak court sentences poet that shot PM to 21 years for ‘terror attack’
